remixlab.proscene
Class InteractiveFrame

java.lang.Object
  remixlab.proscene.Frame
      remixlab.proscene.InteractiveFrame
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Cloneable, MouseGrabber
Direct Known Subclasses:
InteractiveCameraFrame
public class InteractiveFrame
extends Frame
implements MouseGrabber, java.lang.Cloneable

A InteractiveFrame is a Frame that can be rotated and translated using the mouse.

It converts the mouse motion into a translation and an orientation updates. A InteractiveFrame is used to move an object in the scene. Combined with object selection, its MouseGrabber properties and a dynamic update of the scene, the InteractiveFrame introduces a great reactivity in your processing applications.

Nested Class Summary
static class InteractiveFrame.CoordinateSystemConvention
          This enum defines the coordinate system convention which is defined as LEFT_HANDED by default (processing standard).

Constructor Detail

InteractiveFrame

public InteractiveFrame()
Default constructor.

The Frame.translation() is set to (0,0,0), with an identity Frame.rotation() (0,0,0,1) (see Frame constructor for details). The different sensitivities are set to their default values (see rotationSensitivity() , translationSensitivity(), spinningSensitivity() and wheelSensitivity()).

Method Detail

clone

public InteractiveFrame clone()
Implementation of the clone method.

Calls Frame.clone() and makes a deep copy of the remaining object attributes except for prevConstraint (which is shallow copied).

checkIfGrabsMouse

public void checkIfGrabsMouse(int x,
                              int y,
                              Camera camera)
Implementation of the MouseGrabber main method.

The InteractiveFrame grabsMouse() when the mouse is within a 10 pixels region around its Camera.projectedCoordinatesOf(PVector) Frame.position().

Specified by:
checkIfGrabsMouse in interface MouseGrabber

grabsMouse

public boolean grabsMouse()
Returns true when the MouseGrabber grabs the Scene's mouse events.

This flag is set with setGrabsMouse(boolean) by the checkIfGrabsMouse(int, int, Camera) method.

Specified by:
grabsMouse in interface MouseGrabber

setGrabsMouse

public void setGrabsMouse(boolean grabs)
Sets the grabsMouse() flag. Normally used by checkIfGrabsMouse(int, int, Camera).

Specified by:
setGrabsMouse in interface MouseGrabber

isInMouseGrabberPool

public boolean isInMouseGrabberPool()
Returns true if the MouseGrabber is currently in the mouseGrabberPool() list.

Default value is true. When set to false using removeFromMouseGrabberPool(), the Scene no longer checkIfGrabsMouse(int, int, Camera) on this MouseGrabber. Use addInMouseGrabberPool() to insert it back.

Specified by:
isInMouseGrabberPool in interface MouseGrabber

addInMouseGrabberPool

public void addInMouseGrabberPool()
Adds the MouseGrabber in the mouseGrabberPool().

All created MouseGrabber are automatically added in the mouseGrabberPool() by the constructor. Trying to add a MouseGrabber that already isInMouseGrabberPool() has no effect.

Use removeFromMouseGrabberPool() to remove the MouseGrabber from the list, so that it is no longer tested with checkIfGrabsMouse(int, int, Camera) by the Scene, and hence can no longer grab mouse focus. Use isInMouseGrabberPool() to know the current state of the MouseGrabber.

Specified by:
addInMouseGrabberPool in interface MouseGrabber

removeFromMouseGrabberPool

public void removeFromMouseGrabberPool()
Removes the MouseGrabber from the mouseGrabberPool().

See addInMouseGrabberPool() for details. Removing a MouseGrabber that is not in mouseGrabberPool() has no effect.

Specified by:
removeFromMouseGrabberPool in interface MouseGrabber

clearMouseGrabberPool

public void clearMouseGrabberPool()
Clears the mouseGrabberPool().

Use this method only if it is faster to clear the mouseGrabberPool() and then to add back a few MouseGrabbers than to remove each one independently. Use Scene.setMouseTracking(false) instead if you want to disable mouse grabbing.

Specified by:
clearMouseGrabberPool in interface MouseGrabber

setWheelSensitivity

public final void setWheelSensitivity(float sensitivity)
Defines the wheelSensitivity().

rotationSensitivity

public final float rotationSensitivity()
Returns the influence of a mouse displacement on the InteractiveFrame rotation.

Default value is 8.0. With an identical mouse displacement, a higher value will generate a larger rotation (and inversely for lower values). A 0.0 value will forbid InteractiveFrame mouse rotation (see also Frame.constraint()).

See Also:
setRotationSensitivity(float), translationSensitivity(), spinningSensitivity(), wheelSensitivity()

translationSensitivity

public final float translationSensitivity()
Returns the influence of a mouse displacement on the InteractiveFrame translation.

Default value is 1.0. You should not have to modify this value, since with 1.0 the InteractiveFrame precisely stays under the mouse cursor.

With an identical mouse displacement, a higher value will generate a larger translation (and inversely for lower values). A 0.0 value will forbid InteractiveFrame mouse translation (see also Frame.constraint()).

Note: When the InteractiveFrame is used to move a Camera (see the InteractiveCameraFrame class documentation), after zooming on a small region of your scene, the camera may translate too fast. For a camera, it is the Camera.revolveAroundPoint() that exactly matches the mouse displacement. Hence, instead of changing the translationSensitivity(), solve the problem by (temporarily) setting the Camera.revolveAroundPoint() to a point on the zoomed region).

See Also:
setTranslationSensitivity(float), rotationSensitivity(), spinningSensitivity(), wheelSensitivity()

spinningSensitivity

public final float spinningSensitivity()
Returns the minimum mouse speed required (at button release) to make the InteractiveFrame spin().

See spin(), spinningQuaternion() and startSpinning(int) for details.

Mouse speed is expressed in pixels per milliseconds. Default value is 0.3 (300 pixels per second). Use setSpinningSensitivity() to tune this value. A higher value will make spinning more difficult (a value of 100.0 forbids spinning in practice).

See Also:
setSpinningSensitivity(float), translationSensitivity(), rotationSensitivity(), wheelSensitivity()

isSpinning

public final boolean isSpinning()
Returns true when the InteractiveFrame is spinning.

During spinning, spin() rotates the InteractiveFrame by its spinningQuaternion() at a frequency defined when the InteractiveFrame startSpinning(int).

Use startSpinning(int) and stopSpinning() to change this state. Default value is false.

spinningQuaternion

public final Quaternion spinningQuaternion()
Returns the incremental rotation that is applied by spin() to the InteractiveFrame orientation when it isSpinning().

Default value is a null rotation (identity Quaternion). Use setSpinningQuaternion(Quaternion) to change this value.

The spinningQuaternion() axis is defined in the InteractiveFrame coordinate system. You can use Frame.transformOfFrom(PVector, Frame) to convert this axis from an other Frame coordinate system.

setSpinningQuaternion

public final void setSpinningQuaternion(Quaternion spinningQuaternion)
Defines the spinningQuaternion(). Its axis is defined in the InteractiveFrame coordinate system.

stopSpinning

public final void stopSpinning()
Stops the spinning motion started using startSpinning(int). isSpinning() will return false after this call.

startSpinning

public void startSpinning(int updateInterval)
Starts the spinning of the InteractiveFrame.

This method starts a timer that will call spin() every updateInterval milliseconds. The InteractiveFrame isSpinning() until you call stopSpinning().

spin

public void spin()
Rotates the InteractiveFrame by its spinningQuaternion(). Called by a timer when the InteractiveFrame isSpinning().

mousePressEvent

public void mousePressEvent(java.awt.event.MouseEvent event,
                            Camera camera)
Initiates the InteractiveFrame mouse manipulation. Overloading of MouseGrabber.mousePressEvent(MouseEvent, Camera). The mouse behavior depends on which button is pressed.

Specified by:
mousePressEvent in interface MouseGrabber
See Also:
mouseMoveEvent(MouseEvent, Camera), mouseReleaseEvent(MouseEvent, Camera)

mouseMoveEvent

public void mouseMoveEvent(java.awt.event.MouseEvent event,
                           Camera camera)
Modifies the InteractiveFrame according to the mouse motion.

Actual behavior depends on mouse bindings. See the Scene documentation for details.

The camera is used to fit the mouse motion with the display parameters.

Specified by:
mouseMoveEvent in interface MouseGrabber
See Also:
Camera.screenWidth(), Camera.screenHeight(), Camera.fieldOfView()

mouseReleaseEvent

public void mouseReleaseEvent(java.awt.event.MouseEvent event,
                              Camera camera)
Stops the InteractiveFrame mouse manipulation.

Overloading of MouseGrabber.mouseReleaseEvent(MouseEvent, Camera).

If the action was ROTATE MouseAction, a continuous spinning is possible if the speed of the mouse cursor is larger than spinningSensitivity() when the button is released. Press the rotate button again to stop spinning.

Specified by:
mouseReleaseEvent in interface MouseGrabber
See Also:
startSpinning(int), isSpinning()

mouseDoubleClickEvent

public void mouseDoubleClickEvent(java.awt.event.MouseEvent event,
                                  Camera camera)
Overloading of MouseGrabber.mouseDoubleClickEvent(MouseEvent, Camera).

Left button double click aligns the InteractiveFrame with the camera axis (see Frame.alignWithFrame(Frame)). Right button projects the InteractiveFrame on the camera view direction.

Specified by:
mouseDoubleClickEvent in interface MouseGrabber

mouseWheelEvent

public void mouseWheelEvent(java.awt.event.MouseWheelEvent event,
                            Camera camera)
Overloading of MouseGrabber.mouseWheelEvent(MouseWheelEvent, Camera).

Using the wheel is equivalent to a ZOOM MouseAction.

Specified by:
mouseWheelEvent in interface MouseGrabber
See Also:
setWheelSensitivity(float)
